meanings.definition: To put to death, especially by hanging, by mob action and without legal authority.
meanings.sent1: The angry mob decided to lynch the thief without a trial.
meanings.sent2: In the old days, people would sometimes lynch others for crimes.
meanings.sent3: The townspeople planned to lynch the scarecrow for scaring the children.
meanings.sent4: The idea of justice in their town was so twisted that they would lynch first and ask questions later.
meanings.sent5: The image of the hanging rope was a chilling reminder of the mob's tendency to lynch.

meanings.definition: To punish (someone) without legal process or authority.
meanings.sent1: The bullies threatened to lynch the new kid if he didn't give them his lunch money.
meanings.sent2: The dictator would often lynch those who spoke out against him.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous kids joked that they would lynch anyone who didn't like their favorite TV show.
meanings.sent4: The strict teacher seemed to lynch students for the smallest mistakes.
meanings.sent5: The idea of being lynch for breaking the rules kept everyone in line at the school.
